image.altText: Silhouetted figure of a woman to the left, farm gate to the right. Sunset in the centre

items.synopsis: The ABC can reveal there is a court battle to keep a man who abducted and raped a German backpacker 10 years ago behind bars, with forensic psychiatrists fearing he was a high risk of reoffending.

title.children: A German backpacker responded to an ad to nanny in remote Queensland. It was a sex offender's trap

image.altText: People stand around on a street as a tank carrying armed soldiers stands on the street.

items.synopsis: The Russian president has addressed the nation after the Wagner Group staged a mutiny in the southern part of the country, seizing control of the military headquarters in Rostov-on-Don.

title.children: Zelenskyy says 'Russia's weakness is obvious' amid Wagner mercenary rebellion

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Authorities in Russia's Lipetsk region are asking people to stay inside their homes for security reasons. They issued the warning amid reports that mutinous Wagner mercenaries were transiting the region en route to Moscow. The Lipetsk region is around five hours from Moscow via the M4 highway the convoy is travelling on.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Lipetsk authorities tell people to stay indoors as convoy passes

children.content: Authorities in Russia's Lipetsk region are asking people to stay inside their homes for security reasons.
They issued the warning amid reports that mutinous Wagner mercenaries were transiting the region en route to Moscow.
The Lipetsk region is around five hours from Moscow via the M4 highway the convoy is travelling on.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: We've had some questions coming in on what this might mean for Ukraine. Here's our Europe bureau chief Steve Cannane's take: Deb: Ultimately, is this good news for Ukraine? Hope so. Wagner realising they’ve been duped by Putin and turning on him. It is good news for Ukraine. Its armed forces are currently probing the frontlines looking for weaknesses in the early stages of its counteroffensive, and they could well seize on this division. It was Wagner who was responsible for Russia’s only recent military gain in Ukraine – capturing the city of Bakhmut. If its troops are now engaged in blockading Russian cities, rather than fighting in Ukraine that can’t be a good thing for Russia’s military campaign. The morale of Russian troops fighting in Ukraine is already a problem. They have been poorly led, poorly fed and many must be questioning the validity of their mission. Ukrainian soldiers know what they are fighting for – their nation’s very existence. But what are Russian troops fighting for? Now Yevgeny Prigozhin has come out and challenged Putin’s premise of the war – that it was about “denazifying” Ukraine and dealing with the supposed threat of NATO. And what impact might those comments and Prigozhin’s escalation of his attacks on the military high command have on the troops on the ground? As Sir Lawrence Freedman – Emeritus Professor of War Studies at King’s College London has written today: “Once the high command looks vulnerable what will the junior commanders do in their battles with Ukrainian forces? How keen will they be to die for a cause that seems lost?”
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Ultimately, is this good news for Ukraine?

children.content: We've had some questions coming in on what this might mean for Ukraine. Here's our Europe bureau chief Steve Cannane's take:
Ultimately, is this good news for Ukraine? Hope so. Wagner realising they’ve been duped by Putin and turning on him.
It is good news for Ukraine. Its armed forces are currently probing the frontlines looking for weaknesses in the early stages of its counteroffensive, and they could well seize on this division.
It was Wagner who was responsible for Russia’s only recent military gain in Ukraine – capturing the city of

The morale of Russian troops fighting in Ukraine is already a problem.

They have been poorly led, poorly fed and many must be questioning the validity of their mission. Ukrainian soldiers know what they are fighting for – their nation’s very existence. But what are Russian troops fighting for?
has come out and challenged Putin’s premise of the war – that it was about “denazifying” Ukraine and dealing with the supposed threat of NATO.
And what impact might those comments and Prigozhin’s escalation of his attacks on the military high command have on the troops on the ground?
As Sir Lawrence Freedman – Emeritus Professor of War Studies at King’s College London has written today:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Russian army helicopters opened fire on a Wagner mercenary military convoy on the M4 highway outside the city of Voronezh on Saturday, a Reuters witness said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Witness reports army helicopters opened fire on Wagner convoy

children.content: Russian army helicopters opened fire on a Wagner mercenary military convoy on the M4 highway outside the city of Voronezh on Saturday, a Reuters witness said.

image.altText: Fighters of Wagner private mercenary group pose for a picture.

items.synopsis: Russian authorities have accused Mr Prigozhin of staging an armed mutiny after he alleged that the military leadership had killed a huge number of his fighters in an air strike, and vowed to punish them.

title.children: Wagner boss claims all military sites in Russia's Rostov-on-Don are under his group's control

image.altText: Two men stand over Russian Prime Minister Vladimir Putin as he is about to start a meal.

items.synopsis: Vladimir Putin once trusted Yevgeny Prigozhin so much that the assassination-phobic strongman ate at his restaurant. Now Russia has issued an arrest warrant for the man once known as "Putin's chef".

title.children: From 'Putin's chef' to alleged traitor: Here's how Prigozhin's relationship with the Kremlin imploded

image.altText: a picture of one of the Bays on Magnetic Island and surrounding rainforest

items.synopsis: The 26-year-old tourist had celebrated her birthday just last week, according to her employer.

title.children: 'She was a great friend': Belgian tourist dies after motor-scooter crash on island off Queensland coast

image.altText: A photo of a white submersible under water.

items.synopsis: Days of frantic waiting has ended in tragedy for the families of the Titan sub passengers. But the search for answers is just beginning, and the question now is whether lessons will be learned from the underwater implosion.

title.children: The Titan sub mystery unfolded in unimaginable horror. For those on board, it was over in a moment

image.altText: Jim gestures as he speaks at a podium.

items.synopsis: As our federal politicians prepare for their five-week winter break, two significant developments which point to much of what will shape the country — and political debate — in coming months haven't really been quite noticed, writes Laura Tingle.

title.children: We now face the grim expectation we can't avoid a recession — and that's changed the political reality

image.altText: Security personnel keep watch outside the Wuhan Institute of Virology during the visit by the World Health Organisation.

items.synopsis: US intelligence report on COVID-19 origins rejects some points raised by lab leak theory proponents.

title.children: No direct evidence COVID started in Wuhan lab, US report finds

image.altText: Nurses and doctor pictured during medical procedure, generic image.

items.synopsis: The controversial tool has been implemented in Auckland, taking a person's ethnicity into account when placing them on non-urgent surgery waitlists.

title.children: Ethnicity criteria to rank patients for surgery in New Zealand labelled 'a courageous move'

image.altText: Josie Hess has bright red hair and smiles in front of a colourful background

items.synopsis: An international panel of experts has outlined six rules for making healthy, ethical porn. But they're nothing new to regional Victorian porn producer Josie Hess, who wants the edicts to become the norm.

title.children: Is there such a thing as healthy, ethical porn? This filmmaker thinks so — as long as you follow certain rules

image.altText: A silhouette of sharks under a surfer.

items.synopsis: From magnets to smelly wax, electric fields to orca calls, the shark-deterrent market is booming. Here's how the different devices stack up to research.

title.children: Do shark deterrents actually work? We look at the science

image.altText: Creekbed and road overflowing with water outside a house

items.synopsis: A rainband stretching more than 3,000 kilometres will engulf Australia next week, delivering soaking rains from the Pilbara and Kimberley, across the outback to the eastern seaboard.

title.children: Week-long drenching forecast across Australia as El Niño takes a rain check

image.altText: Female hands holding a mobile phone with a dark background.

items.synopsis: A man has helped police track his allegedly stolen ute using a phone app before the driver crashed into a patrol vehicle in the Adelaide Hills.

title.children: Phone app tracks stolen ute as police swoop on alleged thieves

image.altText: A large crocodile resting in the sun on a muddy bank

items.synopsis: A local clean-up group says it is prohibited from removing unmarked pots due to regulations. The matter has come to a head again after a juvenile crocodile was found dead in an unmarked crab pot on the bank of a river in north Queensland.

title.children: Community frustrated after juvenile crocodile drowns while caught in old fishing pot

image.altText: Man makes a coffee at a machine in a cafe.

items.synopsis: Hospitality businesses are raising prices, reducing trading hours and considering scrapping loyalty perks as they struggle to cope with cost of living pressures.

title.children: Paying more for coffee lately? Cafes warn prices will keep rising in 'vicious cycle'

image.altText: A woman holds a bucket of oyster shells in front of the Opera House.

items.synopsis: An Indigenous artist enlists the public's help to clean tens of thousands of oyster shells for a new sculpture reminding visitors of Bennelong Point/Tubowgule's cultural significance.

title.children: Indigenous artist recreates midden at Sydney's Opera House with help of 'scrub club'

image.altText: Aerial view of rows of new houses in outer suburbia.

items.synopsis: Right now, evidence suggests a chronic lack of supply and increased demand for housing are supporting property prices and could lead to a further lift in the market, writes David Taylor.

title.children: How tens of thousands of 'missing' homes could push Australia's property market even higher

image.altText: An Australian female professional golfer watches the progress of a shot down the fairway.

items.synopsis: West Australian Minjee Lee makes her move on the leaderboard at the Women's PGA Championship as she tries to claim her third major.

title.children: Lee rockets up the leaderboard as she looks to claim third major in three years

image.altText: A rugby league player celebrates scoring a try

items.synopsis: Rivals Melbourne and Manly clash in the final NRL game of the night, after both of last year's grand finalists jagged wins. Follow our ScoreCentre for all the live scores and stats.

title.children: NRL live: The Storm-Sea Eagles rivalry resumes in Melbourne

image.altText: Steven Schwartz pictured outside court with a mobile phone and paper work in his hands.

items.synopsis: The US lawyer, a colleague and their Manhattan law firm were fined for submitting fake citations in a court filing.

title.children: 'Use with caution': How ChatGPT landed this US lawyer and his firm in hot water

image.altText: Palestinians take cover during an Israeli raid in Jenin.

items.synopsis: The United Nations human rights high commissioner says conflict in the West Bank is deteriorating sharply, calling on Israel to reset its policies and comply with international law.

title.children: UN calls out Israel for 'use of advanced military weaponry' in deadly West Bank clashes

image.altText: A man surfing a huge wave.

items.synopsis: The massive wave is earning a reputation around the world as it draws daredevil surfers and photographers to the region.

title.children: Surfers take on 'mountain' of a wave fuelled by huge swell off WA's south coast

image.altText: eX de Medici

items.synopsis: In the face of Australia's political conservatism, punk tattoo and visual artist eX de Medici chose a perhaps unlikely weapon: watercolour.

title.children: How a tattoo disaster gave this punk artist an unexpected career twist

image.altText: Close-up of platypus

items.synopsis: A Wildlife Preservation Society of Queensland survey after last year's floods found Sandy Creek, which skirts the edges of western Brisbane and Ipswich, is home to a significant platypus population.

title.children: Between three motorways and in a heavily industrialised area, one of Australia's most elusive creatures can be found

image.altText: A submersible under sea with air bubbles coming out from the top.

items.synopsis: OceanGate co-founder Guillermo Sohnlein defends the company's deceased CEO against claims he dismissed safety warnings, as officials work to decide who will investigate the disaster.

title.children: 'Keenly aware of the risks': OceanGate co-founder defends dead CEO's approach to safety as probe launched

image.altText: Rows and rows of cylinders in cages sit on tarmac. In the background are excavators, trees and water tanks

items.synopsis: This toxic waste dump in Victoria contained everything from PFAS to asbestos — and even cash and a dog wrapped in a mattress — buried in 32 locations, some the size of AFL fields. Now $40 million later, the clean-up is almost complete.

title.children: Inside the massive clean-up of this giant, secret and highly toxic dump — and how it changed recycling for good

image.altText: Fortis House design graphic in front of storm

items.synopsis: After losing his home in the Black Summer bushfires, Greg Webb spent almost $300,000 on extras to disaster-proof his new house. Are such designs a blueprint for the future?

title.children: There's a growing push for more 'resilience' in Australian houses. So what does that look like?

image.altText: A wasp on a tree.

items.synopsis: Scientists find a new biocontrol measure to fight the destructive Sirex wasp, that attacks the softwood pine trees we rely on to build our homes and furniture.

title.children: Parasitic roundworm discovery boosts biological battle against tree-killing wasp

image.altText: A smiling man in a collared, long-sleeved white shirt stands outside NT Parliament House on a sunny day.

items.synopsis: A Northern Territory estimates committee questions the appropriateness of politicians charging taxpayers thousands of dollars for petrol while travelling interstate.

title.children: 'Doesn't pass the pub test': NT politician uses taxpayer funded fuel card for trip through Noosa

image.altText: Two women standing and not looking at each other with view of skyline, mountains and clouds in the background.

items.synopsis: Australian politics is facing a sexual harassment reckoning. Thanks to a crucial scene in a Netflix political drama, so is Taiwan. How did the show Wave Makers become a rallying cry for Taiwan's MeToo movement, and why has it taken so long for people to come forward with allegations of sexual harassment?

title.children: What does 'eating tofu' have to do with Taiwan's rising #MeToo movement?
